23841284.review:
I don't know why, but my girlfriend seems to never look at me with anything less than hatred and I forced a doctor to eat a lot of chocolate.

Press X to Not Die comes off as a high-school production, yet it's technically sound.  It has all the trappings of a 90s FMV game (YMMV on how you feel about that), but improves upon the formula with somewhat branching outcomes.  While your choices won't ultimately affect the storyline, instead of punishing you for "wrong" choices, the game seems to have several different vignettes depending on what path you choose to follow, which is a very nice touch.  Sometimes this leads to unique death sequences which unfortunately require you to watch segments again that you cannot skip, but it's not a deal-breaker.  So why high-school?  The acting is hilariously stiff and jilted and so is the humor.  You might get a chuckle or two, but the game approaches its plot with tongue firmly placed in cheek.

In the end, it's an enjoyable experience, but not something you should be racing to put in your library.

23822976.review:
[h1] Press X To not Die, czyli QTE - The Video Game [/h1]

[i] Naciśnij X, żeby nie dostać w jaja[/i]

Press X To Not Die opiera się przede wszystkim na prostych sekwencjach QTE. Gra w całości w całości wykonana jest w technice full motion video, dzięki czemu możemy doświadczyć dosłownie fotorealistycznej grafiki. Produkcja operuje absurdalnym humorem, który często wyszydza motywy i mechaniki znane z gier komputerowych oraz filmów.

[i] "Jak w tym gównianym filmie M. Nighta Shyamalana"[/i]

Fabuła rzuca nas do miasteczka, którego duża część mieszkańców z niewiadomych przyczyn zaczęła pałać agresją i zabijać się nawzajem. Bohater, w którego przyjdzie się nam wcielić od swojego przyjaciela otrzymuje jedną, prostą radę: "Naciśnij X, żeby nie zginąć". I tak zaczyna się nasza przygoda, w trakcie której będziemy musieli znaleźć naszą dziewczynę, żeby razem bezpiecznie opuścić miasto. W trakcie tej misji będziemy musieli przedrzeć się przez miasteczko unikając krwiożerczych mieszkańców wykonując atakujące nasz zewsząd sekwencje QTE.

[i] "Prawie jak Dark Souls" - J. Sterling[/i]

W grze zginąć możemy na wiele sposobów. Od dźgnięcia nożem przez przebicie kataną na wylot, aż po zgniecenie przez upuszczne metalowe drzwi. Po każdej śmierci będziemy powtarzali osatnią sekwencję. Przycisk (lub przyciski), jakie gra wymaga, abyśmy w danym momencie wcisnęli są losowe, dzięki czemu gry nie da się przejść na pamięć, a o sukcesie decyduje wyłącznie nasz refleks. Ekran z napisem "You died" będzie więc pojawiał się dosyć często.

[i] "Gra dostosowuje się do twoch wyborów. Historia zależy od tego, jak grasz"[/i]

Drzewka dialogowe, niczym w grach od Telltale często prowadzą do róźnych sytuacji i żeby w pełni doświadczyć wszystkich elementów gry trzeba przechodzić ją kilka razy. Pomaga w tym możliwość powtarzania poszczególnych etapów gry, którą otrzymyjemy po jej ukończeniu. Wtedy to również możemy przejrzeć "galerię śmierci", w której możemy zobaczyć ile z możliwych wariantów zgonu udało nam się zaliczyć.

Pomimo, że gra wciąż znajduje się w Early Accsess to z całą pewnością warto się nią zainteresować, oraz czekać na ciąg dalszy tej wspaniałej przygody.

[b] PODSUMOWANIE [/b]

Plusy
+Humor
+Ciekawe wykonanie (FMV)
+Opcje dialogowe prowadzące do róźnych sytuacji
+Kilka poziomów trudności
+Opcja graficzna, która sprawia, że gra wygląda jak z połowy lat 90.
+Materiały zza kulis
+Cena (1.99€)

Minusy
-"Ktotkość" pierwszej części

Końcowa ocena: [b] Fotorealistyczne 6+[/b]

23800977.review:
[h1]20 минут игры за 17 рублей[/h1]

Это вторая видеоигра в прямом смысле этого слова, в которую мне удалось поиграть (первая -- [url=store.steampowered.com/app/341070]Stay Dead Evolution[/url]). Разработчики просто сняли видео на Go Pro и сделали из этого интерактивную игру. К главному герою приходит испуганный друг и сообщает странности, происходящие в городе. Так и начинается наше приключение.

Press X to Not Die проходится примерно за 22 минуты на лёгком уровне сложности, а на безумной сложности, в зависимости от вашей реакции, можно потратить час или два. В игре банальный и абсурдный сюжет, напоминающий дешёвые треш-фильмы, и отсутствует концовка.

Геймплей игры прост: нажимаем необходимые кнопки, когда они высвечиваются на экране. Иногда необходимо выбирать план действия и варианты в диалогах . Пожалуй, это всё, что можно сказать об этой игре.

[b]Положительные стороны:[/b]
-- игра проходится за ~20 минут, но выбивать достижения, может затянуть на два часа и более. Видеоматериалов отснято действительно много, например, можно умереть аж 23 разными способами
-- есть "пасхалки" и забавные варианты ответов. Много весёлых приколов
-- эмоциональные герои, проработанные костюмы, декорации
-- графика в игре лучше, чем в GTA V
-- качественно смонтировано, швов после выбора разных вариантов ответа не замечено
-- русский субтитры
-- интересные достижения

Недостатки:
-- банальный сюжет и малая продолжительность
-- кроме кнопок иногда необходимо нажимать кнопки мыши, что несколько неудобно
-- на повышенной сложности игра пишет, якобы я неправильно нажал кнопки, но я точно нажимал правильно
-- одно достижение получить почти нереально

[b]Вывод: я посмеялся 20 минут, а после выбивал достижения ещё час. Мне не было скучно, забавные пасхалки и некоторые реплики. Если у вас есть чувство юмора и вы хотите получить новый игровой опыт, берите. Если игра не понравится, вы с лёгкостью сможете запросить возврат средств, ведь игра проходится быстро.[/b]

23780154.review:
Все же порекомендую, но  с оговоркой: как бы глупо не звучало, смотря на цену, покупать только на распродажах за бесценок. Даже стоимость бутылки пива за "такое" жалко, а вот "за чупа-чупс" вполне себе прокатит пол часа геймплея.
"Актерское мастерство" местных совсем-не-актеров иногда заставляет закрыть лицо рукой. Но в отдельные моменты когда герои кривляются специально, становится даже весело. Игра регулярно вроде как шутит и стебет сама себя, но делает это как-то неуверенно, актерам судя по всему даже стыдно за то что они говорят "со сцены". Много отсылок и юмора заставляют улыбнуться, но не более. Это не интерактивное кино - это интерактивный ролик на ютуб: короткий, глупый, но в меру веселый. Свою цену вроде как отрабатывает, а большего наверное и не надо.

23771218.review:
[h1]Portable Description[/h1]
Press X to Not Die is a short (~30 min) FMV game filled with cheap humor and predictable QTEs. With various death triggers, nut shots and game endings to experience, be prepared to stay on those fingertips. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[u][b]Full Motion Video[/b][/u]
In a world where a certain type of people are immune to some rage-inducing virus, you must get to your girlfriend and figure out how to survive. This FMV game is comprised of 7 chapters. It will take the player approximately half an hour to reach the end of a single play-through. This interactive movie parodies a lot of common tropes observed in a virus outbreak story; however, Press X is much more laid-back and comedic about it. It even breaks the fourth wall quite often to help develop a more direct interaction with the player, while making fun of itself at times. 

Although this game is extremely amusing, many players may not enjoy the style of comedy or sense of humor Press X employs. The dialogue and script can be too cheesy at times, and the cast is a tad on the ordinary side. From a more technical standpoint, the video clips are often too discontinuous between decisions. A more seamless transition would be ideal.

[u][b]Quick Time Events[/b][/u]
The gameplay of Press X is all about the triggered QTEs, with sprinkles of multiple choice decisions mixed in. On a M&K setup, the game utilizes approximately 9 different keys/buttons to proceed through each QTE. Some will be “press _,” others will be “rapidly press _ and _,” all in an effort to: dodge, hit, swing, run, climb, choke, etc.   

Most of the QTEs will be fairly predictable with regards to timing. If an obstacle, object, or human is suddenly in your path, a QTE will occur. There are very few abrupt QTEs, and upon death, the player will restart from a recent checkpoint (generally immediately before the failed QTE). The button prompts mostly vary, even if redoing a scene. Several QTEs will also need to be failed to achieve specific Steam achievements or discover unseen footage.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u][b]Advised Suggestions[/b][/u]
There are a few suggestions that may improve gameplay listed below.

[list]
[*]Allow the player to skip certain sequences (useful after dying for the 10th time).
[*]Improve the transition of spliced clips between decisions – a little too jarring at times.
[*]Implement dedicated save slots (similar to visual novels) or a “rewind to last decision” option.
[/list]

[u][b]Verdict[/b][/u]
Press X to Not Die is essentially a QTE simulator with a “story”. Unfortunately, the editing, script and dialogue leave a desire for more; however, the lack of FMV games on Steam makes it hard to regret purchasing Press X, especially at such a deeply discounted price ($0.59). The game’s blatant disregard for the fourth wall and plentiful amount of death triggers earn it a recommendation for any non-hypercritical fan of FMV or QTE-heavy games.

[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/BeforeYouBuy]Before You Buy[/url] – analyses of newly released indie games[/td][/tr][/table]

23354664.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[i]Press X to Not Die[/i] is a quirky full motion video game filled with lots of humor and plenty of death. The game is a nice throwback to older games of this nature. Stuck in a world where everyone seems to have gone mad, you have to find away to not die through button mashing on your keyboard or controller. The game is a fun experience that can definitely raise your adrenaline, don’t blink or relax because you never know when you’ll have to press X!

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game starts off like any normal day, that is until your friend rushes over stating that everyone is attacking each other and you have to press X to not die. From that point on you’re thrust into a world where your survival depends on your reaction time.  But don’t worry, you’ll be dying a lot and actually this is the best part. All of the deaths are absurd as is the game itself. You have to rescue your girlfriend, find answers and get out of town in one piece all of this action packed fun is also helped with ridiculous dialogue which is funny and also meta. Don’t worry about the fourth wall, it’s been destroyed. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As the name of the game states, you have to press X to not die. The game works very well using a game controller, however you can also use your keyboard if you like. The game pretty much consists of button mashing action sequences and dialogue choices. Fear not, the game offers a challenge. You have four difficulty modes; easy, medium, hard and then super hard. The amount of buttons you have to press at the same time and the speed at which you have to press them changes with each difficulty. 

[h1]Graphics/Audio[/h1]
This game uses full motion video, meaning everything you see in the game is portrayed by real actors. Every crazy death is acted out and over the top but all done very well. The cheesy humor of the game fits well with the FMV format. The user interface is a bit on the simple side, however this isn’t a huge issue. The whole game is voiced as well so no need to worry there. There isn’t much music in the game but that’s fine, it’s mainly about the action. The game gives you a first person perspective, I however had a bit of an issue with this at first. The movement of camera made me feel uncomfortable but this subsided after some play time. There is also a very retro “1994 mode” which changes the quality of the graphics to what us old farts had to deal with.


[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Great FMV retro feel with good acting.
+ Story is over the top and pretty funny.
+ Four levels of difficulty.
+ Good controls.
+ Steam cards and achievements.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- The language in this game can be rather coarse at times so beware of cursing.
- Thumbs might get tired from all the button mashing.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
As I write this review the game is currently in the Early Access stage, however, I do feel that it’s pretty good as-is and look forward to whatever features get added when it has its full release. If you’re a fan of FMV interactive games then I highly recommend [i]Press X to Not Die[/i], it’s very affordable but also very short. Most of the replay value likes in collecting achievements and unlocking all of the death scenes. While this game may not be for everyone, I really enjoyed it.


[b]Rating:[/b] 9/10

This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games to F2P games.

23323408.review:
This is actually a surprisingly well done "interactive movie" game, that I would have liked to recommend for 30-60 minutes of unapologetic, hilarious B-movie fun.

"Press X" is an Interactive Movie that does not take itself seriously in any way, actually it satirizes the genre\'s many shortcomings. It sports some ridiculously funny lines and events, and the acting - while not stellar - shows great timing for the comedic moments. Most of the game\'s humor is based on bizarre violence and constant breaking of the Fourth Wall, but for a 30-minute experience, that\'s good enough. The game does not overstay its welcome, and its achievement system gives incentive for a second playthrough (also a third if you want to see everything, but at this point the jokes may become a bit stale). Your choices actually do affect future options and conversations, which is very nice.

The story is on the level of the B-movies that the game took inspiration from. The camera is very shaky due to First-Person-perspective filming, gamers who are prone to motion sickness may want to check a gameplay video first. While these criteria would impact a \"serious\" game negatively, I found that they actually contributed to the fun in this parody.

Note: I originally gave this game a negative review due to a pricing policy that I perceived as questionable. However, the devs responded promptly to an email that I also sent them, apologized for the pricing differences, explained how they came to pass, and fixed them. It boils down to an understandable oversight, there was no ill will involved. Since that is out of the way, I can give the game the thumbs-up it deserves.

22772954.review:
(Note: Slight Spoiler Warning)

I woke up. My friend told me that the town was going crazy. He gave me advice critical to my survival... and died. At the hands of a crazy girl. His testimony had been proven in the worst possible way.

I was distraught. This guy apparently cared enough about me to come all the way over to my apartment door and give me a much-needed warning and advice for my survival- and he's dead because of it.

Wanting to share this information, my character dialed up a number to call his girlfri- wait, WHAT!?

Okay; apparently, the character I'm controlling has a girlfriend. I've been single my whole life, personally, and proudly so, but hey, to each his own.

"I" call "my" girlfriend and tell her that my [i]best friend is dead[/i]. All she does is express mild surprise- no grief, no condolences- and then casually mentions he had it coming. Oh, yay. True love.

"I" resolve to go over to her house. You know, because I'm a guy who cares about the woman with whom he's intimate.

I run a distance so long it wasn't even caught on a video clip to get to her house.

I go in, and the first thing she does is, in a bored tone say, "My roommate's trying to kill me."

Her roommate comes at her, and she sidesteps, leaving [i]me[/i] to have to react. This, despite my discovering later that she's perfectly capable of self-defense.

Well, I try to defend myself, and [i]fail[/i], and the crazed roommate kills me...

...and what does "my" girlfriend do?

Come to my aid? Nope.

Call her roommate to distract her? Nope.

[i]Thank me[/i] for taking a knife that was originally intended for her? Nope.

[i]At least[/i] express [i]some[/i] kind of distress at the occuring death of her intimate partner who ran for quite possibly [i]an hour[/i] to make sure she's okay? Or something to show me that I meant something to her and that my sacrifice(s) for her are acknowledged and appreciated?

Nope. Nothing of the sort.

So, what [i]does[/i] she do?

She just stands there casually while her roommate stabs me to death, and the last thing I hear from her is, in a haughty, sneering voice:

"Okay, dying? Not helpful."

If this is what having a girlfriend is like, you hopelessly romantic/sexual idiots out there can all [i]have it[/i].

10/10, this game reminded me why I am happily, eternally single.


[spoiler]Thank you for bearing with me on that. I intend to add a [i]real[/i] review here in good time. [/spoiler]

22536532.review:
The FMV genre has seen a bit of a resurgence over the last few years with the excellent Her Story and Contradiction both standing as head runners of the new age of FMV gaming. Enter Press X to Not Die a relatively short interactive movie FMV game that tries to stand up in a still relatively uncrowded genre.

At only £2.79 going in I was not expecting Casablanca but what I did get was a fun interactive movie with some silly humour and fun references that I enjoyed playing through twice. The game sees you advance through the movie pressing button presses in order to advance the story (think Dragon’s Lair) While X is a common button a decent selection of buttons are used ranging from X to Q to R to mouse buttons. In fact this game is actually harder on the PC than it was when released on Xbox a while ago.

The game is very self-aware about its shortcoming and the nature of the genre and is full of cheesy one liners and self-referential humour. In fact without spoiling too much the idea of the game is brought very much into the game’s over the top ridiculous plot. The time you get to input the commands is adjusted by the difficulty level you choose and the game’s score is given based on how well you do at these points.

The dialogue of the game changes depending on choices you make or how well you complete each section. Deaths and choices are often referred back to by the game’s actors such as chastising you for being a pervert or remarking how many times you have already died. It’s a nice touch that makes you feel like your choices do in some way matter amidst of what is by its very nature a linear game.

The game takes about 30 minutes to complete but for only £2.99 I enjoyed my time with the game and look forward to its sequel.

This review was originally posted here: [url=http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/articles/160420_game-tutor-grades-press-x-not-die] Press X to not Die Review	[/url]

21326531.review:
[quote]Нажмите "В корзину", чтобы купить...[/quote]

Это... это... это... непередаваемо! Я просто потрясён этой игрой! Вот что значит [i]new game experience[/i]!
Прошёл и столько эмоций, уххх! Сразу решил обзор написать! 
Игра - бомба! Есть геймплей, при чём он более разнообразней, чем кажется из названия. Есть завязка сюжета, довольно оригинальная и интересная. Оказывается... [spoiler]не буду раскрывать интригу, сами всё узнаете. ))[/spoiler] Есть даже ИДЕЯ, послание. А ещё юмор, куда же без него. Игра постоянно держит в напряжении и не даёт заскучать. Чем покупать билет в кино на какой-нибудь посредственный фильмец, уж лучше купить эту игруху! 

Честно говоря, это первая моя игра подобного жанра. [spoiler]Возможно этим (в том числе) обусловлены впечатления.[/spoiler] ТАКОГО я не ожидал. Думал, просто понажимаю на кнопочку, посмотрю видеоряд и всё. А тут... Ох, шикарно! Игра подстраивается под вас, "играет" с вами. Так необычно. А ещё этот вид "из глаз"... есть в нём что-то магическое.

Видео снято любительски, и вообще сделано всё на довольно низком уровне, хоть и с душой. А представьте, что будет, если большая студия, имеющая ресурсы, сделает подобное. Чтобы прохождение часа 3-4 занимало. С крутым вариативным сюжетом. С профессиональными актёрами. Мощными спецэффектами и звуком. Фильм, в котором ты - главный герой. Фильм, который ты не просто смотришь, но и в котором участвуешь. Финал зависит от тебя, от твоих слов, решений и действий. Например, "Чужого" так "переснять". Как вам возможность побыть Рипли на борту «Ностромо», а?.. )) Или "Факультет". Про "Пункт назначения" я вообще молчу. Можно даже возможность выбирать героя реализовать. А добавьте к этому низкие системные требования (то есть в такую игру можно будет "играть" даже на [strike]ведре[/strike] медиа-ПК, и наслаждаться "крутой графикой"). А если ещё и поддержку VR запилить... Перспективы открываются грандиозные. 

В общем, игра понравилась, остался под большим впечатлением. Жду продолжения!

P.S. Совет парням. [spoiler]Не делайте моих ошибок, не слушайте девушку, будьте настойчивы! А то придётся мыть пол... (([/spoiler]

Zudem hat das Spiel durchaus einen Wiederspielwert, denn es gibt an einigen Stellen die Möglichkeit, einen Weg zu wählen. Und wenn man wirklich alle Todesszenen sehen will, dann muss man eben nochmal spielen. Das ist aber garnicht schlimm, denn so lang ist das Spiel nun auch wieder nicht.

制作非常用心，素质很高的小品游戏！游戏的组成是：油管娱乐红人风的第一人称真人演出片段，由QTE成功与否（Press X！），加上选择对话选项进行筛选播放（例外的情况也有）。没错，这玩意儿还不是线性的。笑点绝对足，流程时间短但内容绝对饱满，相信有不少人会去玩二周目看看各种死亡动画和分支对话的→_→

20529286.review:
[b]tl;dr -> Tried to peek at my gf taking a shower and she stabbed me. 11/10 "Do you like chocolate?" x1000[/b]

[b]Cons:[/b]

-a bit short (also a positive, as you are meant to complete the game in one sitting)

-quick-time-event (QTE) icons are massive and take over screen – would be nice (maybe in harder difficulties) to have a brief tutorial on the different types of button combos you have to do, then have subtle symbols whenever you need to perform them (like a running-man icon to indicate when you have to press the trigger buttons)

-variable quality in acting (also a positive because of the b-movie-esque feel of the entire game)

-main character does not speak dialogue options (but he still talks in between)

-super comical story

[b]Pros:[/b]

-checkpointing system allows you to continue right after you die

-lots of effort in the scenes – characters will remark on how many times you die, and changes will occur if you try to repeat certain things

-charming, refreshing use of QTE and full-motion-video (FMV)

-super comical story

-finished product intends to have 6 more minutes of content

-great entertainment for a fair price point

I recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/djsfsroguereviews]@DJSF's Rogue Reviews[/url]

20483696.review:
It's an FMV game that consists of a series of QTE's interspersed with attempts at quirky meta-humor. The acting quality... well, if Contradiction was community theater, then this is you and retard friends playing charades, and the answer is "shitty acting". 

I guess you might enjoy that. A few of the gags actually managed to land, and the game is decently reactive - there are a few [b]key choices[/b] you make that get referenced again, and that's kinda cute. You don't get game overs, you just restart right from the failure point, generally just seconds away from the death, which is absolutely the right way to go.

The two main issues: the game is 40 minutes long(and that's after I saw every single death scene) and the camera has an unhealthy interest in the floor and blank sections of wall. Right as the game starts, you get attacked by a not!Zombie, and you have a phone conversation with someone. Throughout the conversation, the camera is fixated on a beige wall, with nothing on it. Apparently both of these are fairly popular complaints, as the "I didn't enjoy this game" options include "too short" and "camera too high" (haha). 

Definitely not worth 4$. Maybe an XBLIG sort of 1$ game.

20468191.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
I bought this on Oct 9, when it launched. From the trailers, it looks stupid. It also harkens back to cheesy FMV games of the 90s, especially horrible titles like A Fork in the Tale. Remember that one, with Rob Schneider? Yeah, didn’t think you did.

I bought it expecting it to be short, but I didn’t expect it to be as funny as it turned out to be, and it’s a surprisingly good game.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Story is oh so typical, but presented with a funny twist
[*]Challenge is excellent on the hardest difficult
[*]Many ways to die, some unexpected
[*]Branching dialogue that changes things up enough that you could get a second playthrough out of it
[*]Terrible voice acting
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Very short, easily finished in under half an hour
[*]Terrible voice acting, yes this was also a pro; it’s basically like a 90s era FMV game, but it’s so out of place in today’s world
[*]Your character is either 12 feet tall, or the GoPro mounted helmet wasn’t the best idea, as your view is staring down at most people, with people clearly craning their neck upwards to see you
[/list]
[h1]Summary[/h1]
It’s quick and it’s stupid, but it’s priced in the right range for what you get. If you grew up playing these kinds of games two decades ago, it’s worth the low cost, and if you like challenge, the hardest difficulty will challenge you greatly. A controller is heartily recommended.

20254800.review:
Just the right amount of bad acting and cringe to make it perfectly funny, the combat system is good, fits the title at least. Funny story-line and the game is good at pointing out how stupidly overused the genre this game is using is(when it's done seriously).

Price point is reasonable.

But I will point out 1 horrible flaw with the game, many people, including myself game left handed, and many of us use left handed mice like the Razer DeathAdder Left-Handed.
If you are one of those people, then bad news, the game doesn't recognize that so when you're promted to press Right Mouse Button you have to press the Left Mouse Button.. That's a very bad flaw and I hope it gets fixed. If you don't understand how annoying this then go in an FPS game and switch your WASD keys to do the opposite, for example W is walk backwards and S is forwards, D is left and A is right.
Try that for 30 minutes in a game like CS:GO and I bet you won't have a lot of fun.
Sorry for the rant but it troubles me that developers do not recognize this.

But, that aside, good game if you're into these kinds of games.

7/10. A nice title if you're into this category of FMV.

And if you enjoyed the infamous Sega FMV games then this is a must-buy title for you.

20147614.review:
求生不如求死系列。——狂魔

↑↑↑↑
这是我上次给《不想死就按X》写的评测，本来是可以起到一针见血醍醐灌顶老谋深算的效果的，可惜这游戏还不那么火，很多朋友都不知道这游戏，所以也就没办法会心一笑默默给我点赞了。那这回我就正经儿地安利一波，让大家知道这么一个很欢乐很逗比的游戏（自带官方简中）。

首先，这是个真人互动游戏，相信不少人都对这种游戏挺感兴趣的。在同类游戏中呢，它即便不是翘楚，也是个风评很不错的高个儿。说到高个儿呢，大家进去玩一会儿就会发现，摄像头好像有点高得离奇了，搞得视角有点怪怪的，不过除了这个之外，其他都还好，演员们的演技都凑合。

然后，为什么它风评很不错呢，这是因为游戏的剧情和对话选项特别逗比，甚至可以猜测是浸淫了史蒂芬周的无厘头风格。有时高分和通关不是重点，QTE失败的后果也值得观赏。游戏不仅人物有点脱线，连对话选项都不时会变得很滑稽，这个时候记得要体验一下，越脱线的选项越好玩，甚至连boss战都能走出惊为天人清新迥异的道路。

作为一个以QTE为卖点的游戏，高能自然和QTE离不开关系。看名字大家应该就能猜到——没错！按X键是游戏的重中之重，是玩家的安身立命之本，主角的好基友马特也是这么说的（虽然很快就变成了杀 · 马特）。然而世事总是弄人的，这里就不剧透那么多，推荐刚开始玩的时候体验一把ridiculous难度，这难度叫做滑稽难度可不是浪得虚名的，它可以将笑果最大化，相信我，老司机诚不欺你好伐。

游戏本身还借没完没了的QTE调侃了游戏主角要按各种按键来行动的设定，当你发现连拿衣服或者锁门都要来遍QTE的时候，真是不禁莞尔了。

另外，游戏还很有点银魂的风格，人物不时表现出“现实代入游戏”的自觉。比如主角的女友会有关于玩家死亡次数的对话，而且处理的很妙，是背对着镜头的时候说的，这样不论说哪个数字都不会有嘴型对不上的问题了（我很想知道他们录了多少个数字的配音）。顺便说一下，坚持不懈地偷看女友洗澡会有好处。

总而言之，《不想死就按X》是个流程不长然而很值得探索各种结果、能够引发各种笑声的优良小品，本身也不贵，推荐大家闲来没事儿的时候玩玩儿。

19743800.review:
Press X to Not Die, is a throwback to the classic quicktime event full motion video games like Dragons Lair, Space Ace, and Braindead 13. FMV is a genre of games where the player would be given a choice to perform an action, or die. Pressing the button for a choice didn’t assure living either, you had to make the right choice, or else your character would still die. Think of the genre as a video version of a choose your own adventure book, that is linear, and a second play through is rarely ever needed.

So now that you know what you would get into with purchasing PXTND generally, how is the game itself? (TLDR at the bottom) I guess to start, the game is linear for most playthroughs, with very little variety on how the game changes based on your decisions. There are 20+ ways to die, and its fairly easy to get through the whole game. The gameplay is as such, watch the video, until the game prompts you to press a button, or a character asks you a question. If you fail to press the right button, more often than not you die, and go back approximately 20 seconds to try again. The answers you give do not seem to seem to change anything for the most part, and that’s the game. I finished it once, and to be honest, there wasn’t a reason to play again for the following reasons:
This is a game that lacks inspiration. Reviving a dead genre is normally done with a goal in mind, a new twist on the same old story; PXTND is not it. The story is more or less first person Dawn of the Dead, the story of how it happens is generic military scheme, and the spoken jokes are outdated pop culture references. Farmville, Twilight, Hunger games, and angry birds are the references, 4 in total that I found, and when they were not out of place (the Twilight reference was just shoehorned in), it became weirdly pretentious (accepting angry bird players, but hating on Farmville…). There were 2 visual gags that made me laugh, if you play the game you will spot them, but overall if someone is trying to sell this game to you as comedy, you will be disappointed. The few jokes are counteracted by the bad acting, which you have to sit through to get through the game.

To start about the bad acting, the game informs me in the extra’s menu that the reason why the acting is bad is because it is purposefully trying to do a callback to bad B movie acting. That is just a lie; when I hear bad B movie acting, I think of overacting, I think of overactive screams, out of place expressions, I think of campy out of place moments and over the top reactions. Don’t let the trailer fool you, the first character Matt nailed B movie. He gives a great intro, lets you know how to play the game, gets shanked, and then lets you know he forgot to press X, FUCKING METAL! That intro, and the fact the game was on sale, is why I purchased the game. For the rest of PXTND the acting past the intro takes a nosedive, the zombies all are doing an impersonation of DOTD zombies, and really don’t bring anything. Again, its college art movie, not B movie, so they lack direction to look like anything other than people pretending to be a zombie/crazed person. Don’t let someone sell you the line that looking like a highschooler filming their first youtube video is what they were going for. It wasn’t funny bad, it was unprepared mess. The biggest problem is the girlfriend in the games acting.

The majority of the game, the only person giving dialogue is your girlfriend. While the zombies in the game try to kill you, she tries to kill the game. No expressions outside of line reading, no emotion, not inflection, just reading the lines. A paper plate on a stick would have been preferred. She brought nothing, and while she is supposed to be the sarcastic death relief (oh you died because…) that didn’t happen. I think the writer was imagining a crazy, spunky girl as he was writing her character, and didn’t envision that someone who looks as stiff as a board through the whole game would be the choice for the lead.

This is the sort of game that reminds me to be wary of the indie community. This just isn’t good, and the people that are adamant that this is the second coming, I think just want to be part of something. It lacks wit, it is using outdated jokes, its pacing is crap, its death scenes are without humor or irony, its 1 liners are out of place, the acting is bad, and not in the fun MST3K way, and the bulk of its jokes are just pop culture references. The game ends with letting you know there is already a planned sequel, but if this was the dream project of someone to revive the FMV genre, and it lacks all of the charms that made those games great, then why would you buy an into an episodic game series that doesn’t seem to have a direction other than making a movie on their Go Pro and taking your money. This could have been shot in a day, written in a day, and programed in a day. This isn’t a passion project, it’s a small developer banking off of the indie community pissing themselves to proclaim how cool they are for playing such a unique pile of crap, that only true Scottsmen get its comedy.

TLDR;
Bad, unfunny acting; Spoken jokes are all pop culture references; Story is the definition of generic; Story is pandering to how Meta gamers are... without irony; No replay-ability; Completely devoid of inspiration; Short (less than 30 minutes), with planned future episodes; Overall a black mark on the already stained FMV genre.

19530844.review:
Aw man, just finished my first playtrough in about 30min and can't stop smiling, this game is hilarious! I didn't expect much when I bought it but it turned out to be really entertaining. 
Basically, the game mechanics consist of multiple-choice dialogues and quick-time events only that determine which FMV sequence is played next -just like in some of the good old FMV games back in the 90s- but the story and the acting are just too much fun to be bothered by little things like that. 
There are online leaderboards, a low-res mode to enforce the aforementioned retro vibe and achievements are placed exactly in the right spots, too. The game doesn't take itself seriously, which dramatically increases its charm. Maybe that's why I like it so much... Footage has been captured with a GoPro Hero 3+ Black Edition btw, just in case you're wondering. The only downer is that the game's so short, however there is some replay value, at least if you're willing to play through all possible choices to see all available FMVs. Considering the game still to be in Early Access phase, there's a chance that the devs will add more content, which I'd personally appreciate very much, but even if they don't this game is definitely worth your time.
All talk aside, I enjoyed Press X To Not Die a lot and I'm really looking forward to part 2 :)

19327319.review:
Press X To Not Die is a game I first saw on YouTube. I thought it would be an interesting experience. So I bought it and I'm glad I did.

This game is kinda like a tribute to those old FMV video games from the early to mid '90s like Wing Commander 3 and Night Trap. I've personally never played those kinds of games, so seeing a video game done in this way was very new to me.
I recommend you play this game on Normal difficulty because the higher ones expect you to press about four buttons in three seconds. Unless you are going for achievements of course.
It's a very short game, but satisfying in many ways. The acting is pretty cheesy which I enjoy personally. The menus feel really well done which surprised me even. 
And yes this game is just quicktime events basically, but one that made me laugh through a lot of it. This game has a strange sense of humor from referring to M. Night Shyamalan to FarmVille. But it does work. I greatly appreciate the use of Kevin MacLeod music by the way, it actually fits nicely here.

Overall, this is a very fun and cheap indie game that I recommend if you just want to be entertained. It doesn't have the same level of substance as most indies I've played, but it is to become a classic in the future!

19034450.review:
[i]Plutôt délaissé depuis l'avancée technique permettant d'avoir des graphismes composés de pixels, le FMV ou film interactif revient cette année soit pour nous livrer une histoire prenante de réalisme, c'est le cas de [i]Her Story[/i], soit pour nous livrer une comédie complètement barrée digne d'un film de série B tel que Press X to Not Die.[/i]

Votre ami Matt vient vous réveiller en catastrophe : les habitants de votre ville semblent devenus fous et se mettent à attaquer tout le monde ! Le secret de votre survie est de presser le bouton X. Vous vous rendez donc chez votre petite-amie afin de la sauver non sans passer par un paquet d'épreuves toutes plus hilarantes et WTFesques les unes que les autres !

Le gameplay du jeu est très simple, il faut suivre les dialogues et réaliser les QTE qui s'affichent à l'écran. Il ne s'agit pas vraiment d'un jeu choix/conséquences comme un jeu Telltale car ici il s'agit plutôt de réussir ses QTE et vivre ou louper et mourir. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=553065796 De toute manière si vous mourez vous reprendrez immédiatement le jeu quelques secondes avant le QTE et vous pourrez réessayer. Le but du jeu étant aussi d'explorer les nombreuses morts grotesques dont vous pourriez faire l'expérience !

Vous avez le choix entre 4 niveaux de difficulté ce qui vous permettra de corser l'expérience si vous trouvez celle-ci trop simple ou au contraire de jouer sans vous prendre la tête si ce qui vous importe est de suivre l'histoire et de rire. Et dites vous bien que s'il y a un jeu qui ne manque pas d'humour c'est bien celui-ci ! http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=553065779 Références cinématographiques loufoques, répliques cocasses, morts ridicules, combats surjoués, esprit série B très marqué...etc. On voit tout de suite que les acteurs ne se prennent pas au sérieux et nous on s'en fiche, on ne cherche pas la révélation de l'année mais le nanar déjanté qui nous fera nous poiler de rire. Pari réussi !

Les graphismes sont superbes, un photo-réalisme inégalé jusqu'alors ! Non, plus sérieusement le jeu est filmé en HD et il y a toujours une petite scène différente selon vos répliques, vos choix, vos réussites ou non lors des QTE... Le jeu s'adapte d'ailleurs dynamiquement à vos choix ce qui est vraiment cool ! Par exemple lorsque vous arrivez chez votre petite-amie vous pourrez lui dire que vous êtes morts tant et tant de fois avant d'arriver là, que sa coloc vous a tué, qu'elle-même a voulu vous tuer...etc selon ce qu'il s'est passé. Il est vrai que le tout est filmé avec beaucoup d'amateurisme, les plans sont pas très bien cadrés, les mouvements sont parfois vifs, le jeu d'acteur est globalement assez mauvais mais cet esprit nanaresque est parfait pour ce jeu qui se revendique d’ailleurs de série B.

Même si le jeu est disponible en accès anticipé il faut savoir qu'il n'est pas pour autant à ses balbutiements. Le jeu est jouable du début à la fin, il manque simplement quelques fonctionnalités que les développeurs veulent implémenter comme d'avantages de scènes, un making-of et des sous-titres. Ce dernier aspect serait en effet une bonne chose pour nous, joueurs non-anglophones car même avec un bon niveau d'anglais il y a parfois des répliques qui nous échappent. A l'heure actuelle [6/12/15] une traduction française est en cours de production, en attendant il reste tout de même très facile de suivre l'histoire globale sans sous-titres.

La durée de vie du jeu est très courte, il est fait pour se jouer d'une traite en comptant environ 30 minutes pour une partie. Rassurez-vous une fois que vous aurez terminé vous n'aurez qu'une envie : recommencer et tester différentes possibilités. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=553065944 Après 2 parties je n'en suis qu'à 70% de scènes découvertes donc il y a encore de quoi faire !

En définitive Press X to Not Die est une vrai bonne pioche pour les amateurs d'humour, de série B ou tout simplement pour les joueurs qui veulent s'essayer à une expérience inédite hilarante. Cependant, ne vous attendez pas à de l'humour fin ou vous pourriez rester hermétiques à l'univers du jeu. Allez, pressez donc X et testez le jeu !

[i]Une clé a été fournie à des fins d'évaluation par les développeurs ce qui n'a néanmoins pas influencé mon avis.[/i]

[quote]Lisez d'autres avis sur ma page de curation : [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9002662/]Kitsune's Guide[/url][/b][/quote]

18845177.review:
I've done two play throughs of this game at this point. First time on Normal and second on Hard. 

My first play through was entertaining and quite humorous - the normal mode can be difficult to someone with slower reflexes and not used to quick time events in games. The acting and dialogue comes off as trying to be ridiculous which I found entertaining. 

Second play through was on hard mode and was considerably more difficult to do the quick time style events. It added more buttons and different combinations which definitely added to the challenge. There is also a higher difficulty level for the crazy people out there.

The game has a high score system integrated into Steam and measures how much of the overall "clips" you've seen or options you have chosen while going through it. 

It's not a super long game, but for someone who wants to challenge the high scores and likes reflex games, it's definitely worth the low price.

18835396.review:
Press X To Refund

You know how for 8-bit/16-bit retro games, there are indie developers who clearly don't know what they play like or feel like? In regards to 8-bit, there are too many colours. Or for 16-bit, the sprites aren't detailed enough. There's an inauthentic feeling that you can't shake.

That's the way I feel about this game. FMV games weren't trying to be bad. In fact, there were good FMV games. There were also just some that were hilariously bad, but they were hilarious because they didn't know better. There was an earnest attempt. A bad movie made by someone who thinks he's talented is better than a movie that's trying to take the [b]pi[/b][b]ss[/b] despite the person knowing they could do better. (Although I have doubts about that if this game is anything to go by.)

Some of the camera shots are just subpar or low quality. Like one scene has your character staring at a blank white wall longer than necessary. Hello? Get a painting or poster or something. There was one shot that had some weird switch between day/night in the middle of a scene, like it was filmed in a single day and they didn't want to wait the extra day to film it for continuity purposes.

The make up effects feel like they're not even trying, which you know, was quite evident they weren't. Like the acting. While I'm sure there weren't robots working on this production, but if you told me there were, I'd believe you. The game talks about "dynamic dialogue", but that's not how it'll come across with actors like these. With maybe the one M. Night Shyamalan joke being kinda funny (although they spoil that in the trailer for the game so you may as well not even play it if you've watched it), the rest of the writing is full of out of place and unfunny pop culture references like Twilight and Hunger Games that don't at all fit.

When you make me think that Family Guy of all things could handle crowbarring in references better, I think you've failed. What's more insulting to me is that there were no jokes making fun of the FMV format, let alone references to classic titles in the genre. Have any of these people even played Tex Murphy, let alone Phantasmagoria?

Oh, and hey guys, 1994 Mode was already done in Stay Dead Evolution, and it's more annoying than accurate. Stay Dead Evolution... now there's a bad game that wore the FMV concept proudly. SDE never tried to sell itself short with a "only kidding!" vibe that crap like this tries to. I certainly don't like Stay Dead, but I'd gladly say it's better than this.

18767725.review:
Remember all the things you loved (or perhaps, hated) about FMV games back in the 90's?  Well, All Seeing Eye Games does and has packed "Press X to Not Die" full of them, along with a bit of self-referential humor and even some current industry tropes along the way.

Like the games from decades past that it undoubtedly draws upon, Press X to Not Die casts YOU as the protagonist in a world that has all of a sudden gone mad.  In true "Interactive Movie" style, the video scenes that follow as the story progresses are shot from your perspective and characters in the game address you directly.  At certain points, you will be presented with a situation that requires a button press (or combination thereof) within a specific time frame depending on the difficulty selected.  At other times, the player selects from a dialog tree or similar to keep things moving.  Though these interactions represent the entirety of the gameplay, the approach here is faithful to the FMV games of yore.  Additionally, the developers have done a fine job of interjecting humor (self-deprecating and otherwise) into the proceedings.

On the standard difficulty, I was able to get through the entirety of the game in just about a half an hour on the first go through with minimal deaths.  While I was a little surprised to have seen the ending that soon, the length of Press X to Not Die is commensurate with the price of admission.  There also exists the possibility of replaying the game several times, whether it be at a higher difficulty or to intentionally not press the required buttons or make different choices to see how the alternate video scenes play out.

In all, Press X to Not Die succeeds as a throwback to a genre that left the spotlight as quickly as it entered it over 20 years ago.  It also succeeds as a tongue in cheek reference regarding why those games had limited appeal and short shelf lives.  Regardless of which one is more prevalent, Press X to Not Die succeeds and is worthy of a purchase.

18481885.review:
The premise of Press X To Not Die is that most people in the town have gone crazy and started attacking each other. It's an interesting twist on the zombie apocalypse scenario.

Pros:

I loved this game and was cracking up from start to finish. The humour is great and the dialogue is clever. The acting is cheesy which perfectly fits the style of the game. The characters were all interesting and crazy in their own unique way. Full disclosure, I do have a soft spot for FMV games. 

Cons:

I played on normal and I did find the difficulty a little high and some of the key press combinations a bit tough. The death scenes were pretty entertaining so I didn't mind failing once, but I was stuck on the boss fight for a while which got a little frustrating. It's also only about 30 minutes of gameplay, although it does have some replayability and the price reflects the length (it's cheap!)

Conclusion:

It calls itself a B movie and that's exactly what it is - an intentionally cheesy and sometimes bizarre FMV game. Its offbeat humour and dialogue keeps it fresh and entertaining the whole way through. If that sounds like your kind of game, I'd snap it up. Also, it says it's early access but I didn't experience any bugs, anything unfinished etc. I'm guessing it's Early Access because there's only the one episode and it's designed to be episodic. Hopefully more episodes are coming!

If you want a peek at the gameplay (or proof that I really did laugh the whole way through!) check out my Let's Play:

https://youtu.be/jhfWN7tFJDs

18464548.review:
I'm giving this game a "recommend" because it's trying something new (for the most part), and because I wouldn't give a "not recommend" to another developer unless they really deserved it.

But here are my major issues with the game:

1. It's missing some very basic things to make the combat feel more exciting.  When I'm punched in the face, why doesn't the camera shake?  Why doesn't the screen flash?  Why isn't there a loud cracking sound?  All of these things would be incredibly easy to add to the video footage, and they'd make combat feel much much better.  These same criticisms also apply when I punch someone else.  

2. The story isn't interesting at all.  It's a basic zombie scenario.  If this wasn't a videogame, I would have lost interest immediately.  How about some mystery?  How about some dramatic conflict? Shawn of the Dead did the whole zombie comedy thing, but there was a ton of drama concerning the relationships between Shawn and his girlfriend, his best friend, and his step-dad.  These things kept me engaged, and they were completely absent here.  

3. The QTE's shouldn't involve both mouse and keyboard.  I have pretty fast reflexes, and I played on "normal", but I messed up the QTE's that involved pressing a mouse button about 90% of the time.  

4. The QTE's where you have to build up a meter by continually pressing a key were way too difficult.  The challenge should be to respond quickly, not to see if I can break my keyboard by jamming a single key at an incredibly high frequency.   I'm guessing these meter challenges feel better on gamepad.

So hopefully some of that stuff can be fixed by the time this game leaves Early Access.  I wish the developers good luck.

18444801.review:
[b]Press X to Not Die[/b] is an indie comedy [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_motion_video]FMV[/url] game that is fun, but is weighted down with quite a few flaws.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

[h1]What is happening in the game:[/h1]
A crazy person is trying to kill you! What should you do? Your friend tells you to press X and you get to live. He presses X too late and he dies. You soon find out that this was not an isolated case as the streets are full of people trying to kill the ones that are healthy. You have to use your reflexes to avoid dying, getting hit and other things.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Comedy[/b] | I had to admit that I had quite a few laughs while playing this. Although the acting was not the best I've seen, I'm pretty sure it was intentional (at least to some degree) and it's able to make you laugh, if you're not too demanding.
    [*][b]The Gameplay[/b] | There are three things you can do in the game: you can choose what to say in a dialog, you have to use reflexes to dodge a punch or to hit someone and you have to mash buttons to run or climb fences. This is actually one of the best things in this game. There are also different difficulties, the higher the difficulty, the more buttons you have to press at the same time.
    [*][b]Production[/b] | There are a lot of short clips put together to form this game and whoever was in charge of coordination and planning did a wonderful job. There are multiple clips which are different every time you die and that really adds another level of quality to the story.
    [*][b]Gamepad and Keyboard Support[/b] | Although this game was meant to be played on a controller, the developers added a setting to play with your keyboard. The controls were ported well and you will find the gameplay enjoyable with any one of those two.
    [*][b]Chapter Selection[/b] | Another thing I really like is the menu in which you can choose between the unlocked chapters. This is great if you, for some reason, didn't complete the story in one sitting or if you just want to select some other text in the dialog answer selection.
    [*][b]Points System and Leaderboards[/b] | As you get points for beating the game, there is Steam Leaderboards support for this game. You also get achievements for beating the game at different difficulties.
    [*][b]Active Developer[/b] | They are releasing updates frequently and they are open to suggestions. They are also planning on adding more features, such as subtitles and even more footage.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Length of the Game[/b] | I completed this game in 25 minutes. Yes, that's right. It is recommended, however, that you play the game on more difficulties to see how far can you push your reflexes. I didn't find the story boring at all even after multiple playthroughs.
    [*][b]Acting Quality[/b] | Imagine a woman saying this line: "Oh, it's you. You're just in time. My roommate is trying to kill me." Now imagine her saying that half-asleep and kind of bored -- that is one example of this game's voice acting. It's not very good, if you haven't guess yet. I have a feeling that it's intentionally bad, but sometimes it's just too bad.
    [*][b]Poor Steam Integration[/b] | [strike]You cannot use Steam Overlay and you can only see your newly gained achievements after you close the game. Clunky.[/strike] [b]This was fixed with the latest update. Good job, developers![/b]
    [*][b]Instability[/b] | When I was playing it, this game crashed a few times and one of the results of this was a lost achievement. Not a big deal, though, as this seems to be occurring rarely.
[/list]

[h1]The final verdict:[/h1]
I had a hard time deciding how to grade this game, but I decided that all the positive sides outweigh the negative ones. It's true that the acting is bad and the whole game is short, but I really liked it and I can't wait for the next episode! I'm not sure whether the price is appropriate or not, but the game is going to be updated with more content, anyway. I hope that the next episode will be given to current owners for free and not as a DLC or a separate game, as this would really not please people who thought that this episode was too short (everyone).
I recommend this if you're looking for a quick laugh and are not too demanding when it comes to acting quality.

Greetings,
BirdCute

[quote]Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.[/quote]

[i]---
If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]
18444801.developer_response:
Thank you so much for your detailed review, BirdCute.  We really appreciate it.  We would like to correct a couple points:
1. We did a speed run of the game and it took 20 minutes from the start of the game to the beginning of the credits.  We are fairly certain it is physically impossible to complete the game in less time than this while a typical playthrough would take about 25 minutes.
2. We have no control over the Steam Overlay.  Any issue with it would have been an issue with Steam itself at the time.  Perhaps this was the source of your instability as well?  We have not received any other reports of crashes.

18441083.review: Short, cute fun.  It's clever, it's light.  More importantly it's a proof of concept for a new era of FMV interactives, an approach that GoPro has democratised, and which should spawn a whole lot of really interesting games in a variety of genres going forward.  In a few years we may be sitting around talking about Press X to Not Die as we do Dear Esther today: a game that may not be the best of its kind, but whose character and wit created a space for others to come into to make some truly great games.  And for that I suspect we will be thankful.  So thank you in advance, Press X to Not Die, for all the games that are yet to be made, and for this, a really cute, really fun little experience.  I look forward to Part 2.
